entry.title: Using TIP to Unit-Test Non-Invasively
Creating a Singleton Configuration Manager
entry.content:
Why Use a Configuration Manager?

In enterprise application development, loose coupling between tiers is paramount to building a reusable, extensible solution. One of the best ways to enforce loose coupling is to make sure that the lower layers (i.e. tiers) of an application are unaware of those on top of it. Its this idea that has spawned the event-heavy paradigm available in contemporary programming languages.

In MS.NET, we have a few different options for persisting and retrieving configuration data for an application. Probably the most familiar is the ubiquitous configuration file, but there's a host of other ways to store this information: as simple text, as xml, or in the Windows registry. Regardless of how you choose to store this information, however, it is likely that you will need to make it available throughout your application. This means that accessing a domain specific configuration file say web.config directly from other layers violates the concept of loose coupling and undermines encapsulation. Plus, there is no guarantee that the application requiring configuration data will be executing under a specific context (HttpContext, for example).

This means that, in the case of an n-tier application where business objects may be used by multiple user-interfaces, we cannot rely on intrinsic access to configuration files. You'll have to decide whether to roll your own configuration schema, manually parse the configuration files, or use some other configuration tool like the Windows registry or the Microsoft Enterprise Library Configuration Application Block.

In any event, we need an architecture that facilitates these requirements, while allowing us easy, efficient access to our configuration data. Enter the singleton configuration manager.

The Singleton Pattern

Singleton is a design pattern made famous by the so-called Gang of Four in Design Patterns. Essentially, singleton is used to ensure that one and only one instance of an object ever exists in memory. This pattern works very nicely for classes whose data is the same for all users of an application, especially if this data changes infrequently in these cases there is little justification for the overhead of instantiating the same object over and over. For retrieving static configuration data, singleton is a perfect fit.

Project Setup

For the sake of simplicity, the sample solution includes only the configuration manager project, a simple web project, and a sample registry merge file. Click here to download the solution.

Creating the ConfigurationManager Class

Setting up the singleton class is straight-forward. The singleton pattern is very easy to implement: make the constructor private, add a static member variable to hold the sole instance of the class, and create an Instance method to return this member. Its also good practice to implement a lock anytime you are accessing a static member:
public class ConfigurationManager
      
{
      
  private static volatile ConfigurationManager _instance = null;
      
  private static object _instanceLock = new object();
      

      
  public static ConfigurationManager Instance()
      
  {
      
    if (_instance == null)
      
    {
      
      lock (_instanceLock)
      
      {
      
        if (_instance == null)
      
        {
      
          _instance = new ConfigurationManager();
      
        }
      
      }
      
    }
      
    return _instance;
      
  }
      
}
Now that we have the foundation for our singleton in place, all we need to do is implement accessors to retrieve our properties from the appropriate location. In this example, Im using the Windows registry:
public sealed class ConfigurationManager
      
{
      
  private const string mConnectionString = “ConnectionString”;
      
  private const string mAppRegKey = “SOFTWARE\\bettersoftwarenow\\samples\\configurationManager”;
      
  private static volatile ConfigurationManager _instance = null;
      
  private static object _instanceLock = new object();
      

      
  public String DbConnectionString
      
  {
      
    get
      
    {
      
      String cnString = null;
      
      cnString = (string)GetObjectValueFromRegistrg(mConnectionString);
      
      return cnString;
      
    }
      
  }
      

      
  public static ConfigurationManager Instance()
      
  {
      
    if (_instance == null)
      
    {
      
      lock (_instanceLock)
      
      {
      
        if (_instance == null)
      
        {
      
          _instance = new ConfigurationManager();
      
        }
      
      }
      
    }
      
    return _instance;
      
  }
      

      
  private object GetObjectValueFromRegistry(string valueName)
      
  {
      
    object regValue = null;
      
    using (RegistryKey regKey = Registry.LocalMachine.OpenSubKey(
      
      ConfigurationManager.mAppRegKey))
      
    {
      
      if (regKey != null)
      
      {
      
        regValue = regKey.GetValue(valueName);
      
        regKey.Close();
      
      }
      
      else
      
      {
      
        regValue = null;
      
      }
      
    }
      
    return regValue;
      
  }
      
}
To access the ConfigurationManager from anywhere else in the solution, you just instantiate using the static Instance method. You can then use the class just like you would any other, except that future calls to instance will return a reference to the instance already in memory:
public class _Default : Page
      
{
      
  private ConfigurationManager _config = ConfigurationManager.Instance();
      

      
  private void Page_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
      
  {
      
    if (!IsPostBack)
      
    {
      
      string cnString = _config.DbConnectionString;
      
      // code to use db connection string
      
    }
      
  }
      

      
  // remainder of class ommited
      
}

Using a single point to retrieve configuration information will make your application far more flexible, will help eliminate duplication of this data across layers, and will prevent tight coupling between your applications tiers. Building this functionality using a singleton design pattern adds an element of simplicity to your application, while yielding a small performance advantage at runtime.

klc;

entry.title: Support for .NET's CLR Growing?
entry.content:
Microsoft has done an amazing job with the .NET CLR. Despite what the naysayers might have you believe, the CLR's open architecture has made it a very attractive option to other (read: non-Microsoft) language developers. And the speed with which these new languages can be created is staggering. Testament to this: the math-heavy F# research language and Fujitsu's .NET port of COBOL, NetCobol.

klc;

entry.title: Embracing Software Change
entry.content:
Early in my career as a programmer, a mentor warned me about committing what he considered to be the cardinal sin of software development. "Kris", he said, "never change software that works." Foolishly, I followed this advice for a few years before I realized its fallacies.

His justification for this philosophy amounted to "if it ain't broke, don't fix it." But this thinking raises several semantic questions. Most importantly, how do you define broken software? Is it characterized by critical defects, by imperfection, or by both? Or is it something else altogether? And when do you stop "fixing" broken software?

My mentor, it would seem, had done me a great disservice. His advice taught me that software is characteristically unstable and unchanging, and that&mdashtry as we might&mdashthere's no way to adequately test software before it is released.

Fortunately for me, I finally saw the bigger picture. Fortunately for software, folks don't always follow this mantra. Windows 3.1 wasn't broken, but Microsoft chose to improve it anyways. The i286 was capable machine, yet we have the Pentium. Such thinking serves only to stifle innovation.

Besides, in the software business there are several schools that embrace the idea of change. Agile development methodologies recognize change as a fundamental part of the development process. Refactoring tools, performance testing, and design patterns all encourage us to constantly improve our software...

These ideas aren't new of course, but they are slowly seeping further into mainstream mentality. More and more copies of Fowler's classic Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code are appearing on office bookshelves, there's a preponderance of quality refactoring tools available, and Agile methodologies are popping up in shops traditionally resigned to more heavyweight approaches.

The next few years should will demonstrate how well these techniques really work. But if you've spent any amount of time working with them, you already know that they do. You also probably know how difficult it can be to evangelize them and how frequent the roadblocks are, but that's another story.

In any event, it's nice to see that we sometimes actually embrace change.

klc;

entry.title: Got UML Fever?
entry.content:
The UML is a very effective software design tool. It can help us stay agile, communicate with brevity, and prove concepts without hammering out a single line of code. Yes, UML is an effective too—that is, when used by a qualified practitioner. Boeing's Alex Bell eloquently outlines just when UML might be your enemy in UML Fever: Diagnosis and Recovery (link compliments of ACM Queue).

entry.title: Required Reading List
entry.content:
Questions I hear frequently from developers are, what are the best practices for developing an API? and, whats the best architecture for my classes? or, how do I correctly design an n-tier application?

I always get excited when people ask questions like this, because they are indicators for three very important qualities in a software developer: software is probably being designed by this person, there is acknowledgment of best practice, and the m.o. is efficacy.

Yet, there's usually no simple answer. Staying ahead of the proverbial curve is a full-time endeavor itself one that requires dedication, focus, and attention to detail. Mastering the fundamentals is critical, and this quality is very often what sets a true engineer apart from the crowd. Remember, its not the length of experience that matters it is the experience itself.

In any event, I do have a suggested reading list that I share with anyone who asks, and I'm always open to new recommendations:

  • Agile Project Management with Scrum
  • Code Complete
  • Design Patterns
  • Microsoft Design Guidelines for Class Library Developers
  • Microsoft Patterns and Practices
  • The New Methodology
  • Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture
  • Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code
  • Test-Driven Development in Microsoft .NET
  • UML Distilled: A Brief Guide to the Standard Object Modeling Language, Third Edition


klc;

entry.title: Versioning .NET Assemblies Using NAnt
Keeping SQL Junk Out of Your Web App
entry.content:
I was recently reminded of the dangers of not handling SQL injections in input validation while testing a web app about to go into production. Don't let this one fall through the cracks! Make sure that your development and QA teams are well-educated on SQL injection (and XSS attacks for that matter), and make sure that they have ample time to examine the intricacies of any third-party UI controls being used in the UI.

While searching the Net for some good reference materials for exactly this purpose, I came across a 2002 whitepaper Advanced SQL Injection In SQL Server Applications, written by Chris Anley of NGS Software which does just this quite well. Chris does a great job of reminding us of just how simple it is to catastrophically affect a SQL server using only a few basic characters.

klc;

link.title: Keeping SQL Junk Out of Your Web App

entry.title: Automate MSI Generation Using WiX
entry.content:
Automated build tools like NAnt can streamline your build process and alleviate some of the headaches of team integration. But using these tools to build a Setup and Deployment project is another story its impossible to build a setup project using csc, and the MSI task in NAnt leaves much to be desired.

Enter WiX, an XML-based, scriptable, toolset originally developed by Microsoft that can be used to automate the build of an MSI. Using WiX, part of the output from your build can be an up-to-date installer for your product.

While extremely powerful and flexible, WiX is also somewhat of an enigma. Its fairly complex and not very well documented. But not to worry Microsoft installer guru Rob Mensching has published an excellent article on MSDN explaining how WiX works and how you can use it in your build process.

entry.title: Programmer's Bill of Rights
entry.content:
Recent months have seen a welcomed turnaround for developers. As the economy has steadily improved and the number of professional developers on the marked has steadily decreased, the demand for high-quality talent has skyrocketed. Yet Im surprised to still find shops running high-pressure, high-turnover code-mills reminiscent of the two years following the dot-com bust.

Sadly, we have no one to blame for this phenomenon but ourselves. Allowing an employer or customer to operate a software sweatshop ultimately serves no best interest we burn out, our family life suffers, and our customer gets a low quality product.

Its our responsibility as professionals to carefully manage our customers and our industrys expectations, else we tacitly approve a trend that can only damage us.

To this end, Ive constructed a simple list of terms that you can (venture I say, should) reasonably demand of your customer or employer:

Programmers Bill of Rights

1. You are entitled to respect.

2. You have the right to honest, open dialog with your customer.

3. Your technical vision is a valuable asset and should be treated as such.

4. You have the right to maintain an uncompromising commitment to quality.

5. You have the right to use the tools you need to best do your job.

6. You have the right to manage change.

7. You have the right to fair pay and shouldnt be expected to work for free.

8. You have the right to work reasonable hours.

9. You have the right to put your family first. Coworkers are NOT your family.

10. You have the right to not compromise your integrity.

11. You have the right to have fun and enjoy your work.

klc;

entry.title: Microsoft Enterprise Library 1.0
Tools to Make MS.NET Development Easier, Faster, and Cleaner
entry.content:
Anything that can make building software faster, easier, or more enjoyable is a welcomed addition to my toolkit. I've been seeking out more of these tools over the past few months - primarily as my interest in agile methodologies has grown - and have been consistently impressed with the number of high-quality, open-source, free tools available to MS.NET developers.

To this end, I've added links to utilities that have proven themselves on the lefthand side of my blog. You'll likely notice a strong slant toward those that can automate any part of the development process or that facilitate agile development.

Here's an (updated) summary of the tools I've currently listed:

Cruise Control .NET - ThoughtWorks' powerful continuous integration platform is an excellent tool for use alongside lightweight methodologies like XP and Scrum. CCNet integrates very well with build tools like NAnt, NDoc, and the like; and can automate many of the mundane build tasks like deployment, archiving, time/version stamping files, etc.

Fiddler - One of the most frustrating parts of debugging a web application is not knowing exactly what is happening between the server and web browser at the session level. You can resort to sniffing tools, but these are almost always focused at too low of a level to be readily useful. Enter Fiddler, a browser session level inspection utility. Fiddler is far and away one of the coolest utilities I've used.

FormShield - I quickly learned about FormShield when a friend's blog was being filled with garbage from offshore casinos and Viagra dealers. DotNetFreak Kevin Gearing has done the blogging community a noble service by giving us this tool.

FxCop - Microsoft's free code analysis tool for .Net, FxCop validates managed code against Micorosft's official Design Guidelines. It almost always generates more warnings than you could ever hope to address, but its a great resource for identifying critical issues in your applications. Just for fun, try running FxCop against itself :)

Microsoft Enterprise Library - Originally known as the Application Blocks, the Enterprise Library includes several modules that provide ubiquitous services to your applications. Cryptography, data access, exception handling, and event logging are all handled consistently through a relatively small API. The project, developed jointly by the Patterns and Practices group at Microsoft and Avanade, Inc. is also a model of pattern-based software architecture.

NAnt - Port of the Java world's Ant built tool. NAnt is a incredibly powerful, Xml-driven build tool that integrates well with CI tools like Cruise Control.

NDoc - I consistently drive developers crazy with my insistence on comprehensive interal documentation. But its hard to argue against when you see the beautiful output NDoc generates when run against code that makes good use of .NET's XmlDoc tags. Having  NDoc run as part of a CI cycle and then publishing to the development team is a priceless on complex or disparate projects.

NMock - Used in conjunction with NUnit, NMock gives you a framework for rapidly creating mock objects for developer testing. Highly useful in projects where access to resources like databases are very expensive or impossible to access, or for death-march projects where parallel processes force an unnatural development order.

NUnit - NUnit, a port of the well-loved JUnit, is ubiquitous with test driven development in .Net. It's also a great debugging container for n-tier applications, allowing you to step into lower levels of code directly.

Reflector - Lutz Roeders amazingly useful tool providing insight into the innards of .NET assemblies. Reflector is an excellent debugging tool, optimization tool, learning tool, and development tool.

SR Generator - If you've spent any time looking through the Enterprise Library source, you've run into this gem. The SR tool automates the generation of resource files using a format supposedly used internally at Microsoft, and provides access to resources entries to your code via constants. I've found a marked reduction in resource-manager related runtime errors in my projects by using the SR Tool.

Wix - If you're using automated build tools for .Net projects, you've probably learned that you can't build a setup and deployment project from the command-line using csc. Enter Wix, Microsoft's free, Xml-driven MSI generator. Developing MSIs using Wix can get a little complex, but the good news is that the bulk of the work is one-off (and reusable). The Wix toolkit also contains a utility called Dark, that will reverse engineer a working MSI into Wix format!

I'm always looking for feedback, recommendations, or tips on new tools or how to better use what I've listed.

klc;

link.title: Tools to Make MS.NET Development Easier, Faster, and Cleaner

entry.title: Using Flash with .NET Web Services

Neddle
entry.content:
Neddle is an open source, SCORM compliant learning management system (LMS) built on the .NET platform using C#. Neddle was created to address the absence of a truly high-quality, commercial grade LMS in the OSS community. The project has several goals:

  • Create a viable open source alternative to paid LMS solutions.
  • Build a product that technilogically advanced, yet simple in its use.
  • Provide functionality and a user experience that is truly student and educator centric.
  • Include SCORM conformance that is actually useful.
  • Provide a rich set of course authoring tools and third-party tool integration options.
  • Fit well with a wide variety of training paradigms, including corporate training, institutional teaching, and commercial services.
  • Build vibrant on- and off-line communities around that platform.
  • Keep installation, management, and use and use of the product by non-technical end users as simple as possible.
  • Provide tight integration with the Windows operating system.
  • Provide workable options for use in shared and cloud hosting environments.
  • Provide tight integration with other Windows platform products; namely SharePoint, popular shopping cart applications, and popular merchant gateway services.
  • Feel good about giving something back to the OS community.
  • Have fun and learn in the process.

We have other, longer term goals such as developing a solid installation package, adding mobile support, and possibly adding support for various cloud database platforms. We're also very much interested in eating our own dog food. Once a RC is ready, we will self-hosting training on all aspects of system use at the official project website.

Our project team is highly selective. At present, we're working through the initial architectural planning and low level development, and are not actively recruiting new developers. That said, if you're a .NET or SQL rockstar with experience building or extending LMS platforms or SCORM tools, please drop me a line at http://neddle.codeplex.com.

entry.title: DotNetCRM
entry.content:
DotNetCRM Community Edition is an open source, enterprise-class CRM built on the .NET platform. It is designed to be extensible, pluggable, configurable, database agnostic, and includes a well-documented C# API. The project has several primary goals. Notably, we'd like to:

  • Create a viable open source alternative to paid CRM solutions.
  • Build vibrant on- and off-line communities around that platform.
  • Keep installation, management, and use and use of the product by non-technical end users as simple as possible.
  • Provide tight integration with the Windows operating system.
  • Provide workable options for use in shared and cloud hosting environments.
  • Eventually provide tight integration with other Windows platform products, e.g. SharePoint, MSCS, and so on.
  • Eventually provide tight integration with popular LOB and SaaS applications.
  • Feel good about giving something back to the OS community.
  • Have fun.

The project is currently being completely restructured from a previous, uncompleted, and long-forgotten version. This has turned out to be a bit of a chore, and it has largely meant just starting over. The short term roadmap for the product consists of:

  • Migrating (what's left of) the codebase to .NET 4.0.
  • Migrating the primary database platform to MSSQL 2008 (though there are discussions on whether to support others).
  • Reevaluating and redeveloping the domain model.
  • Improving data access by taking advantage of new features in .NET.
  • Improving support for long-running business transactions.
  • Design and implementation of an AJAX-based front end.
  • Miscellaneous refactoring and cleanup.
  • Performing a sanity check on and accurately memorializing the product backlog.
We have other, longer term goals such as developing a solid installation package, building WPF client tools, adding mobile support, and adding support for various cloud database platforms. And, of course, any promising feature requests that come from the community at large.

If you're interested in helping, visit the project site at http://dotnetcrm.codeplex.com.

entry.title: I run from most things that get in the way of my p...

I run from most things that get in the way of my professional development.


You can buy my pride and I can spin wheels and waste time, but my monkey fees may break your bank.

entry.title: Using common sense is a subjective matter and the ...
entry.content:
Using common sense is a subjective matter and the perspective of each person in the same development team will definitely be a different one simply because there are differences in the way people treat people, therefore there is not a single correct answer to the question at hand.


Here is my own common sense perspective on the very scenario being discussed.


First of all, if indeed one is uncomfortable at being part of it, I think it is okay to leave a project that has all the negatives already mentioned in this conversation.


Now, there is no question in my mind [that it is time to depart!] when, in the same project scenario, aggravating circumstances arise such as when payment for ones already rendered work is delayed for two months without anybody noticing it but the affected one (what does that tell about the client objectives, priorities, ethics, etc.?).


After all, isn't the main reason for working, to make a decent leaving? In order to achieve a sustained career that is professionally and ethically sound, one must associate oneself with those that behave at least up to ones own standards of professionalism and ethics.


Having said all that, if one is capable of enduring and stays no matter what and the project ends up being successful (another subjectivism) then, one would have attained an incomparable sense of success and indeed priceless pride.


Unequivocally, only one would now what is the right course of action according to ones own circumstance, and if it feels right go for it!


Raul

entry.title: First of all, there is nothing wrong with being as...
entry.content:
First of all, there is nothing wrong with being associated with a failed project. As long as you are able to step back and objectively evaluate the root causes of the failure, and learn from the mistakes made (no matter whose fault they may be). How can anyone know how to succeed unless they have seen the path to failure?


Besides, failure is only a matter of perspective. As the [former] Iraq Information Minister would spin it: "We have them surrounded in their tanks!".


To answer your question - it is almost always worse to abandon a failing project than it is to see it through to the (possibly inevitable) conclusion.


But - there are a few exceptions that I think are worth mentioning. Either of which qualify for telling the client to go to hell (yes, I have experienced all):


1. Your client is not operating legitimately. They are either involved in illegal activities or their business model is based on a scam.


2. Your client is not being professional. Whether they are harassing you, violating your contract, or otherwise just not treating you with professional respect. I actually had a client once who was taking the code I produced, and giving it to a competitor of mine.


3. You are not being allowed to do quality work. You might have offered a solution to the problem, but your client refuses to address it. If it prevents you from delivering quality work, then you have the right to protect your professional reputation by refusing to deliver a sub-standard product.


4. I am sure there are more exceptions that I have yet to encounter...



Raul: I am sorry but I hold no sympathy for your experiences with delayed payment. If you cannot handle waiting two months for a check (and want to jump ship because of it), then Contracting is definately NOT for you. I consider a client that always pays in under 60 days to be a miracle. I have waited as long as nine months for a single payment from one of my more beaurocratic clients. It is not uncommon at all to go for three to four months without ANY pay.

entry.title: I believe I'm tracking well with the conversat...
entry.content:
I believe I'm tracking well with the conversation that is going on here, and I wanted to share some reactions to the original poster and those who have followed:


1) If 80 hour work weeks are happening and the client doesn't do anything to change that, the client is not only being unprofessional, they are wasting their money. I don't care how good an individual programmer is, sustained hours like this will cause burn out and mistakes.


2) Clients that do not pay in a reasonable amount of time according to the contract are in breach of contract and activities with the client can legally be stopped. If payment terms are not specified (only a rate), they can wait quite a while before it gets serious (although the invoice should also have the terms, such as "On Receipt" or "Net 30").


3) Whether or not one leaves a contract in advance of the expiration date involves so many factors, that it is difficult to sum up in words. I would probably draw some type of quadrant to help me graph damage to client and damage to individual which would then serve as a decision factor. If damage to the individual is high and your departure would have minimal impact, then leave... they will find someone else to donate the pound of flesh. If your departure would cause great damage to the client, then you should be given a greater voice to control the outcome. The responsibility level can not be that high without you having more control over the outcome. If this can not be provided, then leave, the project was doomed from the beginning and no amount of effort you provide will counteract the downward slide.

entry.title: All very salient points. One thing to keep in mind...
entry.content: All very salient points. One thing to keep in mind: while I agree that it's generally bad-business to ignore payment terms, I have to agree with Keith. As a vendor, you must be able to accept delayed payments - and the sometimes dirty work that goes along with collecting them.

entry.title: You'll already know this Kris, but not everyon...
entry.content:
You'll already know this Kris, but not everyone reading may: Using Singletons in a web environment can leads to issues with multithreading. I have seen this error several times on projects where a developer thinks he has a singleton for each session; not true, a singleton is just that - one instance across the entire app domain :) These can be tricky defects to track down.


There is an article on MSDN somewhere talking about it, but I just remember to engage my brain that step further when working with Singletons in a web project.

entry.title: Thanks for the comment Paul. Indeed a very importa...
entry.content: Thanks for the comment Paul. Indeed a very important popint - one I should have made more clear in the original article. The purpose of the singleton implementation I suggest is to provide application-wide data, without coupling to web-specific objects like Application or Session.

entry.title: I've been pretty careful not to endorse any co...
entry.content: I've been pretty careful not to endorse any commercial products. But after spending the past three days evaluating Document! X, I must say that this is a VERY impressive product. Not only does it document .NET assemblies, but it will also create docs for databases, ActiveX components, VB6 applications, and the like. The learning curve is a little steep - as is the price - but if you're developing apps for which you need top-notch documentation, I think you'll find that Document! X is well worth the costs.

entry.title: Where are you hosting the CS? I need to upgrade as...
entry.content: Where are you hosting the CS? I need to upgrade as well from .TEXT to CS

entry.title: Albert, Doug Rohm and I are both hosting our CS we...
entry.content:
Albert, Doug Rohm and I are both hosting our CS websites are ORCS. I have several other friends and associates who also use them, and I routinely send my customers there. Simply put, te service at ORCS is second to none.

Know that you've got a long road ahead of you upgrading from .Text to CS2.x. Your best bet will probably be to migrate from .Text to CS1.1 (there are some excellent tools out there to help you do this, see some of my earlier posts on CS for links), and then move from CS1.1 to 2.0. Good luck!

entry.title: Probably you have a place were you can stay, eat, ...
entry.content: Probably you have a place were you can stay, eat, a computer to work and all the other stuff for free. Let me know, I want to move there to and start working on open source.

entry.title: Nope. I've worked my ass off so that I have a ...
entry.content:
Nope. I've worked my ass off so that I have a place to stay, food to eat, a computer to work on, software to code with, and all the "other stuff". None of these things have been given to me for "free". Any time that I (or most anyone else, I'd suspect) spend working on an open source project is completely unrelated to making a living -- I do it because I want to, because it makes me feel good, because I can learn from it.

If you're looking for tips on getting a free ride, go elsewhere.

entry.title: Since most folks use PCs, I don't see this bec...
entry.content:
Since most folks use PCs, I don't see this becoming a real problem anytime soon. Isn't the audience just too small?

I'm an Apple user.

"...persuade with little regard for the facts."
Imagine if the ad was a discussion that contained all of the facts. That wouldn't be nearly as effective.

Ultimately, I'm not sure how far off the campaign is. To me it's not negative. I've worked along-side a couple of folks designing graphics on PCs, and except for maybe a few small technical issues with fonts, everything went smoothly.

That said, I don't know of any art directors that work on anything other than a Mac.

On the other hand, there are problems working in Microsoft development environments on a Mac. I don't think there is a MS Visual Studio for Mac, but then again I don't know any Mac users that would really want to use it.

We could have an ad centered around complex data processing, and how Mac users wouldn't want to do it, but that would surely fail as an ad. It would also be a copy, and that's another issue altogether...

entry.title: Doug and I have contacted Kevin several times to r...
entry.content:
Doug and I have contacted Kevin several times to request that he hand the project over. Our requests have gone unanswered. To Kevin's credit, I'd like to think that he's just been swamped with emails. But I'm a little afraid that he's just washed his hands of it completely.

We'll continue to try until Kevin either gives us the project or hands it over to someone else -- at which point Doug and I will be the first to sign up to help.

I'll keep you posted. If you hear anything though the grapvine in the meantime, please let me know.

entry.title: I've never developed any open source applicati...
entry.content: I've never developed any open source applications, but with over 10 years experience in the PC Desktop development world, I think it's time I should 'give back' to the community. I'm putting my hand up (along with anybody else) to be involved in bringing this project back to life. It is a more mature product than Sandcastle, the output looks better, and it has a user interface. I realize that Sandcastle is beta, but I can't use it in it's current state. I am using NDoc today for .net 2.0. Is there any chance of picking up the recent source code release from Jonas Lagerblad? Feel free to email me on 'paul at sigmasix dot co dot nz'
